fields.description:
This is a summary of logging enhancements on the back end that entered the code base around 3.2 release, but have been in "tech preview" status due to lack of QA. At this point, if the features are worthy of full support, this ticket should be targeted appropriately and the features are to be QAed and documented.

Back-end components (CC and NC) have two new configuration parameters related to logging:

*1) LOGPREFIX*

LOGPREFIX allows cloud admin to customize the beginning of each log line. 

When not set, the prefix is determined by the log level. From ERROR until INFO levels, the prefix is short, consisting of just the timestamp and the log level. At DEBUG and TRACE levels, thread ID and function name are added to the prefix. At TRACE level, file name and line number of the logging statement are added, too.

When set, the value of LOGPREFIX overrides the default prefixes _at all levels_. The syntax for the prefix may use the following wildcards, similar to the way wildcards in printf() are substituted with textual values:

* %T = timestamp
* %L = loglevel
* %p = PID
* %t = thread id (same as PID in CC)
* %m = method/function
* %F = file:line_no
* %s = max rss size, in MB

Furthermore, wildcards p, t, m, F may be followed by (-)NNN, where ( - ) optionally requests left-justification and NNN is the maximum length of the field size. For instance, the default prefixes for each log level are defined as follows:

{code}
const char *log_level_prefix[] = {
    "",
    "%T %L %t9 %m-24 %F-33 |",         // EXTREME
    "%T %L %t9 %m-24 |",               // TRACE
    "%T %L %t9 %m-24 |",               // DEBUG
    "%T %L |",                         // INFO
    "%T %L |",                         // WARN
    "%T %L |",                         // ERROR
    "%T %L |",                         // FATAL
    ""
};
{code}

Quite likely, LOGPREFIX is most useful in combination with the second new option:

*2) LOGFACILITY*

Allows to request logging to a syslog facility. If not set, no attempt to open system log or write to it will be made. If set, the value must be one of the syslog facilities, as listed in {{/usr/include/sys/syslog.h}}:

{code}
CODE facilitynames[] =
  {
    { "auth", LOG_AUTH },
    { "authpriv", LOG_AUTHPRIV },
    { "cron", LOG_CRON },
    { "daemon", LOG_DAEMON },
    { "ftp", LOG_FTP },
    { "kern", LOG_KERN },
    { "lpr", LOG_LPR },
    { "mail", LOG_MAIL },
    { "mark", INTERNAL_MARK },          /* INTERNAL */
    { "news", LOG_NEWS },
    { "security", LOG_AUTH },           /* DEPRECATED */
    { "syslog", LOG_SYSLOG },
    { "user", LOG_USER },
    { "uucp", LOG_UUCP },
    { "local0", LOG_LOCAL0 },
    { "local1", LOG_LOCAL1 },
    { "local2", LOG_LOCAL2 },
    { "local3", LOG_LOCAL3 },
    { "local4", LOG_LOCAL4 },
    { "local5", LOG_LOCAL5 },
    { "local6", LOG_LOCAL6 },
    { "local7", LOG_LOCAL7 },
    { NULL, -1 }
  };
{code}

The name of the log will be {{euca-nc}} or {{euca-cc}}, depending on the component.

Eucalyptus log levels are mapped to syslog levels as follows:

* euca -> syslog
* EXTREME -> DEBUG
* TRACE -> DEBUG
* DEBUG -> DEBUG
* INFO -> INFO
* WARN -> WARN
* ERROR -> ERROR

Logging to syslog may be used in parallel with regular back-end logging. If only syslog is desired, the admin can set {{LOGMAXSIZE}} parameter to 0 in order to suppress logging to nc.log or cc.log.
fields.summary: Back-end logging enhancements (syslog support and prefix customization)

comments.body:
Hey [~dmitrii],

Just to make sure I understand, if the cloud admin configures this, by default, will logs go both to cc.log/nc.log and syslog?  The reason why I ask, is because typically, when configuring applications to use the default system syslog or a application specific log file, the application has more of a defined "use syslog, or use this log file" type method of configuration.  Setting LOGMAXSIZE to 0 to just go to syslog seems more like a "short cut".  Everything else here looks good. In short, I would suggest we have something more direct, like a variable that is used to define where logging should take place.  Here are a couple of examples below:

*_OpenLDAP_*
* Using [slapd-config|http://linux.die.net/man/5/slapd-config], you can define the variable olcLogFile => 
** olcLogFile: <filename>
Specify a file for recording debug log messages. By default these messages only go to stderr and are not recorded anywhere else. Specifying a logfile copies messages to both stderr and the logfile.

*_Apache_*
* Using the [ErrorLog directive in Apache|http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#errorlog], you can configure either to use a specific log file or syslogd =>
** The ErrorLog directive sets the name of the file to which the server will log any errors it encounters. If the file-path is not absolute then it is assumed to be relative to the ServerRoot.
*** _ErrorLog "/var/log/httpd/error_log"_
** If the file-path begins with a pipe character "|" then it is assumed to be a command to spawn to handle the error log. See the notes on piped logs for more information.
*** _ErrorLog "|/usr/local/bin/httpd_errors"_
** Using syslog instead of a filename enables logging via syslogd(8) if the system supports it. The default is to use syslog facility local7, but you can override this by using the syslog:facility syntax where facility can be one of the names usually documented in syslog(1). The facility is effectively global, and if it is changed in individual virtual hosts, the final facility specified affects the entire server.
*** _ErrorLog syslog:user_

I hope this helps give more insight to my questions and clarification on configuring the destination of logging.  Please let me know if there are any additional questions.

Regards,

Harold Spencer, Jr.

[~dmitrii],

Additionally, can we expect later on down the road, a single consistent way to configure syslogging?  For example, here this references the NC and CC, but can we get a similar logging interface for the other Eucalyptus components?  For reference, here is a recent email sent out explaining how to do logging for the Java components (i.e. CLC, Walrus, VMwareBroker, SC).  As you can see, there are similar concepts, but it would be really helpful if we could have one Eucalyptus defined way of configuring syslog for any component.  Thoughts?

*__snippet of email__*

The objective is to get a log file which contains the user requests that are being made using euca2ools.  The query API used by euca2ools has a log event which occurs, but has two issues which keep it from the logs in the normal configuration.  It is:
- logged at the TRACE level
- explicit category redirects to cloud-exhaust.log (and so is lost almost instantly even at TRACE level)

The plan is to have a log file which contains these log messages by massaging the default log4j.xml appropriately.

What we did was:
1. Introduced a site-local log4j.xml file by (roughly):
(cd /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d
unzip /usr/share/eucalyptus-core*.jar log4j.xml
)

2. Amended the site-local log4j.xml file to introduce a new appender (log file) for the log messages.  It looks like the following:
<appender name="API-log" class="org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender">
  <param name="Threshold" value="TRACE" />
  <param name="File" value="${euca.log.dir}/api.log" />
  <param name="MaxFileSize" value="10MB" />
  <param name="MaxBackupIndex" value="10" />
  <layout class="org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout">
    <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d{EEE MMM d HH:mm:ss yyyy} %5p [%c{1}:%t] [%C.%M(%F):%L] %m%n" />
  </layout>
</appender>


3. Modified the existing category entry for com.eucalyptus.ws.util.HmacUtils (where the LOG.trace occurs) to have a 'priority' of 'TRACE' and an 'appender-ref' to the new log 'api.log'.  It looks like the following:
<category name="com.eucalyptus.ws.util.HmacUtils" additivity="false">
  <priority value="TRACE" />
  <appender-ref ref="API-log" />
</category>

This did not have the desired effect -- no messages were logged.  Because of time constraints the remaining steps (which I failed to identify immediately)  are listed below.

The next thing is to actually get message to go to the appender.  For that to happen some witchcraft is needed:
- The messages are logged at TRACE level.  If the cloud were run at TRACE level they would show up using the log4j.xml that we have at the end of step #3.  But that would be bad for the system.

4. To get messages to go to the appender it needs to be attached to the '<root>' appender -- this makes all log messages also go to that appender.
 <root>
   <appender-ref ref="${euca.log.appender}" />
   <appender-ref ref="errorlog" />
+    <appender-ref ref="API-log" />
 </root>

5. Now, because the 'API-log' has a 'Threshold' of 'TRACE' every message will get logged to it, even ones we don't want.  To restrict 'API-log' to only have the messages we want the best thing I can think to do is filter the messages by the string prefix that shows up in the each of the request log entries.  When they are logged the messages look like this:


The corresonding config bit introduces a string match filter for 'VERSION2:' (these log entries will be 'ACCEPT'ed and written out) followed by a filter which 'REJECT's all other log messages:
<appender name="API-log" class="org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender">
  <param name="Threshold" value="TRACE" />
  <param name="File" value="${euca.log.dir}/api.log" />
  <param name="MaxFileSize" value="10MB" />
  <param name="MaxBackupIndex" value="10" />
+    <filter class="org.apache.log4j.varia.StringMatchFilter">
+      <param name="StringToMatch" value="VERSION2:" />
+      <param name="AcceptOnMatch" value="true" />
+    </filter>
+    <filter class="org.apache.log4j.varia.DenyAllFilter" />
  <layout class="org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout">
    <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d{EEE MMM d HH:mm:ss yyyy} %5p [%c{1}:%t] [%C.%M(%
  </layout>
</appender>

6.  Restart 'eucalyptus-cloud' to get the changes reloaded and then check 'api.log'

[~hspencer] I thought we had documented how to do syslog/rsyslog with the java components already?  Maybe it was [~graziano]?  I can't seem to find it on the intertubes.

Long story short, it looks something like this:
# Extract {{log4j.xml}} (from {{eucalyptus-core-*.jar}} into {{/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d}}
# For each of the {{appender}}s (which currently all write to log files) to be redirected to syslog, replace the {{${appender}}} stanza in {{log4j.xml}} with a {{SyslogAppender}}.  The following example redirects {{console-log}} (aka. {{cloud-output.log}}) to {{LOCAL1}} and {{logfile}} (aka. {{cloud-debug.log}}) to {{LOCAL0}} on localhost.
{code}
diff --git a/clc/modules/core/src/main/resources/log4j.xml b/clc/modules/core/src/main/resources/log4j.xml
index 55cd29d..d48b3c8 100644
--- a/clc/modules/core/src/main/resources/log4j.xml
+++ b/clc/modules/core/src/main/resources/log4j.xml
@@ -77,17 +77,16 @@
       <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d{EEE MMM d HH:mm:ss yyyy} %5p [%C.%M(%F):%L] %m%n" />
     </layout>
   </appender>
-  <appender name="console-log" class="org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender">
+  <appender name="console-log" class="org.apache.log4j.net.SyslogAppender">
+    <param name="Facility" value="LOCAL1" />
+    <param name="SyslogHost" value="localhost" />
     <param name="Threshold" value="${euca.log.level}" />
-    <param name="File" value="${euca.log.dir}/cloud-output.log" />
-    <param name="MaxFileSize" value="10MB" />
-    <param name="MaxBackupIndex" value="10" />
     <layout class="com.eucalyptus.system.EucaLayout" />
   </appender>
-  <appender name="logfile" class="org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender">
-    <param name="File" value="${euca.log.dir}/cloud-debug.log" />
-    <param name="MaxFileSize" value="10MB" />
-    <param name="MaxBackupIndex" value="10" />
+  <appender name="logfile" class="org.apache.log4j.net.SyslogAppender">
+    <param name="Facility" value="LOCAL0" />
+    <param name="SyslogHost" value="localhost" />
+    <param name="Threshold" value="${euca.log.level}" />
     <layout class="org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout">
       <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d{EEE MMM d HH:mm:ss yyyy} %5p [%c{1}:%t] [%C.%M(%F):%L] %m%n" />
     </layout>
{code}
# Restart eucalyptus-cloud

See http://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/apidocs/org/apache/log4j/net/SyslogAppender.html for more details.

Hey, [~hspencer]!

Yes, you understand correctly, that setting LOGFACILITY results in logging to both component's file log and to syslog. I am surprised you would prefer an either/or option, since that is less flexible. I understand that sys admins may like syslog, but if I am on a customer installation trying to dig through Euca logs, I think I'd want to have the option to enable plain file logging both so that I don't have to figure out their syslog setup and so that I can control verbosity at finer level than syslog allows: we have DEBUG, TRACE, and EXTREME in Euca, while syslog only has one level past INFO.

As for one way to control logging on all components, that's clearly desirable, but is challenging, given the architecture of the system. I'd say if syslog usage gets popular and this emerges as a pain point, it may be worth looking into. In a sense, this is just one of many examples of differences between configuring C-based components (via eucalyptus.conf) and Java-based components (via properties).
Are LOGPREFIX and LOGFACILITY entries added to eucalyptus.conf for each node ?
Each node has a eucalyptus.conf, so yes.

Hey [~dmitrii], 

Having it go to both syslog and a eucalyptus log file doubles up the space taken on the system.  Also, if a customer has syslog enabled, you can control the granularity of verbosity based upon the syslog config file for different applications.  This is available for not only syslog, but also other logging systems like rsyslog.

*Reference*

* http://www.freebsd.org/doc/handbook/configtuning-syslog.html
* http://www.rsyslog.com/doc/rsconf1_includeconfig.html
* http://linux.die.net/man/5/syslog.conf

The flexibility here is to be able to use syslog/rsyslog.log file or a specific log file location. 

As far as syslog having only one log level past INFO - I am confused regarding that statement.  Per man page:

{code}
The priority is one of the following keywords, in ascending order: debug, info, notice, warning, warn (same as warning), err, error (same as err), crit, alert, emerg, panic (same as emerg). The keywords error, warn and panic are deprecated and should not be used anymore. The priority defines the severity of the message
{code}

Am I misunderstanding your statement?

Hey, [~hspencer],

Sure, the two type of logging would double the space, but only if you choose both options. The difference is just between having to change *one* config field versus *two* config fields. Considering the many perils of changing our config files, this one seems like a minor inconvenience, which gets us greater flexibility.

The flexibility I am referring two is the ability to use *both* syslog and the file, compared to only being able to use either.

My point about the levels is that we have more of them than syslog. Syslog only has 'debug', while we have 'debug', 'trace', and 'extreme', all three of which are useful in different circumstances.

Hey [~dmitrii],

I think we were saying the same thing..:-).  I wasn't saying just use syslog; I was saying you can configure eucalyptus to use either option.  You just clarified with this sentence here:

{code}
Sure, the two type of logging would double the space, but only if you choose both options. The difference is just between having to change one config field versus two config fields.
{code}

Thanks for the clarification.

Cheers,

Harold Spencer, Jr.
Great, I am glad we're on the same page, [~hspencer]. Thanks for the input.
Closing this summary bug.

Thanks, [~shashi], for checking with our folks in the field. I would certainly love to hear from them on whether syslog is working. But, after a more careful thought, I think I closed this ticket prematurely. Its intent was not only to document the behavior, but also to serve as a reminder to QA the new functionality. I am re-opening the ticket and, after a conversation with [~viglesias], targeting it for 3.3.1, as we probably will not get to test it before 3.3.0 GAs. Again, the code is there, as is, and all feedback is welcome, it's just that any fixes required won't make it into 3.3.0.

Thanks [~dmitrii] for the clarification. I agree that we should continue to actively test this in the field and provide any feedback for us to harden this for a 3.3.1 release, if possible. So, my previous request to [~hspencer], [~edeleon], [~dstagnaro] still stands unchanged :-). Thanks.
